sentences: Brian Patrick Carroll (born May 13, 1969), known professionally as Buckethead, is an American musician, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist.
section: N/A

sentences: He has received critical acclaim for his innovative electric guitar playing.
section: N/A

sentences: His music spans several genres, including progressive metal, funk, blues, bluegrass, ambient, and avant-garde music.
section: N/A

sentences: He performs primarily as a solo artist, although he collaborated with a wide variety of artists such as Bill Laswell, Bootsy Collins, Bernie Worrell, Iggy Pop, Les Claypool, Serj Tankian, Bill Moseley, Mike Patton, Viggo Mortensen, That 1 Guy, Bassnectar, and Skating Polly.
section: N/A

sentences: He was also a member of Guns N' Roses from 2000 to 2004.
section: N/A

sentences: He has recorded 325 studio albums, four special releases, and one EP.
section: N/A

sentences: He has performed on more than fifty albums by other artists.
section: N/A

sentences: Buckethead performs wearing a KFC bucket on his head, emblazoned with an orange bumper sticker reading FUNERAL in block letters, and an expressionless plain white mask inspired by Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers.
section: N/A

sentences: At one point, he changed to a plain white bucket without a KFC logo, but subsequently reverted to his emblematic KFC bucket, but without the funeral sticker.
section: N/A

sentences: He also incorporates nunchaku and robot dancing into his stage performances.
section: N/A

sentences: Buckethead is voted Number Eight on a list in GuitarOne magazine of the "Top 10 Fastest Guitar Shredders" as well as being included in Guitar World's lists of the "25 all-time weirdest guitarists" and the "50 fastest guitarists of all time".
section: N/A

== Early and personal life ==

sentences: Early and personal life ==
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: Brian Patrick Carroll was born on May 13, 1969 to Tom and Nancy Carroll and is the youngest of five siblings along with Lynn, Lisa, Lori, and John.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: His father was the Athletic Director at Damien High School in La Verne, California, from 1973 until his retirement in 2013.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: Carroll grew up in a Southern California suburb near Disneyland.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: In his youth, he was an introvert, and spent most of his time in his room with books, games, martial-arts movie memorabilia, and toys.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: He also spent a lot of time at Disneyland.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: Carroll began playing guitar at the age of 12.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: He learned to play from an elderly man down the road.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: He is quoted as saying, however, he became serious a year later after he moved from Huntington Beach, California to Claremont.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: His playing improved with lessons from various teachers at a local music store.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: His early teachers included Max McGuire, Johnny Fortune, Mark Hammond, Pebber Brown, Joey Tafolla, and Paul Gilbert.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: In 2003, Buckethead played a tribute to all his early teachers as the Deli Creeps played a show at Styles Music's 25th anniversary.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: He then began making demo recordings of both his playing as well as his writing styles, which would later be released in 2007–2008.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: The Buckethead persona came to be when Carroll saw the 1988 horror movie Halloween 4 and was inspired by the film.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: He went out right after seeing it and bought a Michael Myers-like white mask.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: The bucket idea came later that night while eating chicken:
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: I was eating it, and I put the mask on and then the bucket on my head.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: I went to the mirror.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: I just said, 'Buckethead.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: That's Buckethead right there.'
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: It was just one of those things.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: After that, I wanted to be that thing all the time.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: In October 2017, Carroll gave a rare out-of-character interview discussing all ranges of his life, the Buckethead character, his parents' deaths, his health problems, and how he copes with overcoming fear.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: During the podcast, he revealed he has been diagnosed with the potentially life-threatening condition of heart arrhythmia.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: He stated he had a cardiac ablation performed and uses medicine to control the problem.
section: == Early and personal life ==

sentences: In 1988, after leaving the band Class-X, Carroll entered a song called "Brazos" into a Guitar Player magazine contest.

sentences: It was a runner-up, with editors writing:
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: An astonishingly skilled guitarist and bassist
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: , he demonstrates post-Paul Gilbert speed and accuracy filtered through very kinky harmonic sensibilities.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: His psychotronic, demonic edge is very, very far removed from the clichés of classical metal and rock.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: A real talent to watch, also known as "Buckethead."
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: In the same year, the magazine's editor, Jas Obrecht, came to know of Buckethead when Carroll and his parents left a demo recording at the magazine's reception desk for Obrecht.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Impressed with this demo, he rushed into the restaurant where Buckethead and his parents were having lunch and encouraged him to make the most of his talent.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: They soon became friends.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: In 1989, a song called "Soowee" by Buckethead got honorable mention in another song contest.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: In 1991, Buckethead moved into Obrecht's basement.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: The song "Brazos" was eventually released on the 1991 demo tape of his band Deli Creeps, titled "Tribal Rites", and again as bonus material in Buckethead's Secret Recipe DVD in 2006.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Luke Sacco was his teacher.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: In 1991, Buckethead contributed to Derek Bailey's Company project alongside, among others, John Zorn and Alexander Bălănescu, resulting in a triple album called Company 91.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: After his first two demo tapes, called Giant Robot and Bucketheadland Blueprints, Buckethead released Bucketheadland on John Zorn's Japanese Avant record label in 1992.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Though available only as a pricey import, the record received positive reviews and earned some attention.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: At about this time, Buckethead fell into the orbit of prolific bassist/producer Bill Laswell, himself an occasional Zorn collaborator; Buckethead (as a performer, producer, or composer) was introduced to Laswell with the help of Limbomaniacs drummer Bryan "Brain" Mantia, who gave Laswell a video of Buckethead playing in his room.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Buckethead soon became Laswell's second staple guitar player, besides Nicky Skopelitis.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: In 1992, Buckethead, with Bill Laswell, Bernie Worrell, Bootsy Collins, and Bryan "Brain" Mantia, formed the supergroup Praxis.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Their first album, Transmutation (Mutatis Mutandis), released the same year, was well received.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: The project was Bill Laswell's concept, and has since involved other guests such as Serj Tankian of System of a Down, among many others.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Buckethead participated in every release except the initial 1984 release and Mold (1998).
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: In 1993, Buckethead auditioned to play for the Red Hot Chili Peppers.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: The band eventually ended up with Arik Marshall, and later Dave Navarro.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: After some legal complications with Sony Music Entertainment, Buckethead decided to release his 1994 album Dreamatorium under the name of Death Cube K (an anagram).
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Death Cube K is a separate entity that looks like a photographic negative version of Buckethead with a black chrome mask, like Darth Vader.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: This apparition haunts Buckethead and appears in his nightmares.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: Buckethead released a second studio album that year, Giant Robot, which features many guest appearances by artists such as Iggy Pop and Bill Moseley.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1994: Early solo career and Praxis ===

sentences: The name of the album came from the Japanese series Johnny Sokko and his Flying Robot, of which Buckethead is a fan.

sentences: He also released two other albums with Praxis, their second and third studio efforts: Sacrifist and Metatron.

section: == Career == | === 2011–2015: Focus on solo Pikes ===

== Influences ==

sentences: Influences ==
section: == Influences ==

sentences: Buckethead cites a wide variety of musical influences, including Michael Jackson, Parliament-Funkadelic, Shawn Lane, Michael Schenker, Uli Jon Roth, Paul Gilbert, Yngwie Malmsteen, Joe Satriani, Eddie Hazel, Randy Rhoads, Larry LaLonde, Mike Patton, James Cutri, Louis Johnson, Jimi Hendrix, Jennifer Batten, The Residents, Eddie Van Halen and Angus Young, as well as the many artists he has collaborated with over the years.
section: == Influences ==

sentences: In addition to his musical influences, Buckethead cites a diverse range of non-musical influences manifested in several ways out of which dedicated songs to said inspirations have been a staple of Buckethead's discography with  particular attention to basketball players like Michael Jordan (songs "Jordan" and "Jump Man", album "Happy Birthday MJ 23"), George Gervin (on "Iceman"), Blake Griffin (on "Crack the Sky" and "Griffin's Spike"), "Pistol" Pete Maravich (on "The Mark of Davis"), LeBron James (with four songs dedicated to him), and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (album "Kareem's Footprint").
section: == Influences ==

sentences: Other influences include martial artist and actor Bruce Lee (on "The Game of Death" song and inspiration behind the use of nunchakus on stage), author H. P. Lovecraft (on the "Lurker at the Threshold" suite, and his 55th Pike, The Miskatonic Scale), numerous science fiction and horror TV shows and movies including Little House on the Prairie, Alejandro Jodorowsky's The Holy Mountain (on Kaleidoscalp), and Giant Robot (mentioned on several songs, albums, and episodes shown on stage).
section: == Influences ==

sentences: Disney and Disneyland are also major influences on Buckethead's career.
section: == Influences ==

sentences: Buckethead is also inspired by Japanese filmmaker Takashi Miike, to whom a song on Pepper's Ghost is dedicated.
section: == Influences ==

sentences: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre franchise of movies is also a big inspiration to him and he has written many songs such as Jowls, which are heavily inspired by those movies.
section: == Influences ==

sentences: The song "To Infinity and Beyond" from Out Orbit was dedicated to then-recently deceased basketball reporter Craig Sager.
section: == Influences ==
